Duo_Maxwell

Panel Sends Bolton Nomination to Senate 
 
 WASHINGTON - John R. Bolton, President Bush's sharp-elbowed nominee to become U.N. ambassador, survived a cliffhanger Senate committee vote Thursday after renewed criticism from both Democrats and Republicans, leaving the final confirmation decision to the full Senate....
 
 http://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/ap/20050513/ap_on_go_co/un_ambassador
 
 Voinovich is only speaking out because he can afford it. The rest of the republicans don't have as stable ground to vote aganist or give such harsh words with elections comming soon. 
 
 Either way, I agree with Voinovich's statements, particuarly the private sector comment. 
 
 Bolton is horrible for the job, and perhaps the right will realize that when we are paying for everything in our next adventure.

 You should talk to Fracas about this plan of yours. He has something simmiliar, and as far as I recall it, it was pretty interesting. He seems to share the idea that an international organisation based on democratic states is preferable to the current system where China and Russia has as much influence as the US and France. I can agre that this is a problem, but I would consider the exclussion of representation for a majority of independant nation-states an even larger problem...

I've been toying with the idea of a institution where the influence of states is based on a variety of factors: population, economic strength, military strength, political freedom, human rights, form of government, trade liberalisation, level of foreign aid, level of funding to said institution, level of particpation in peacekeepers and humanitarian aid operations, if the state sponsors terrorists etc
 
 A system that recognises the position of countries in the world as well as encouraging human rights, democracy etc (and possibly free trade or environemntal protection if that's what your into)

 One could argue that it would be an incentive for those less free states to clean up their acts. It would also be an incentive for already free states to watch their "p's" and "q's." Theoretically, if in fact our Iraq war was wrong, it would have had an immeasurably greater effect on our policy had it been widely perceived within the U.S. government and our citizens if we didn't already believe that the existing body, the U.N, was not dominated by a collection of bloody tyrants and crooked wheeler-dealers.
 
 In order for any organization to have credibility and respect it must tell the truth and not deal off the bottom of the deck. The U.N. is utterly corrupt and I would argue worse than useless. I would go so far as to say it is a malignant cancer on world politics.

 I don`t think the Iraqi invasion would have been handled differently by an organisation purely based on (liberal) democratic regimes. The bloody tyrants and crooked wheeler-dealers where pretty ambivalent on the issue of Iraqi invasion. Certain middle-eastern countries where very opposed (like Iran, Syria) but other despotic dictatorships did approve of it (like Pakistan, Uzbekistan or Kuwait). 
 
 On the other hand the democratic regimes in Europe was divided on the issue, Australia did approve, Canada silently disaproved (or did they aprove?) Japan didn`t really care, Israel was jumping up and down with joy :p etc, etc.
 
 There was a rift in the issue, but the trenchlines did not run between democratic nations and dictatorships.
 
 
In order for any organization to have credibility and respect it must tell the truth and not deal off the bottom of the deck. The U.N. is utterly corrupt and I would argue worse than useless. I would go so far as to say it is a malignant cancer on world politics.

 
 UN is currently experiencing a rather serious crisis. There are certain structural problems that needs to be addressed (the power of the security council for example) as well as other problems that are not structural (like alledged corruption, US distrust of UN capabilities), but the idea of an international organisation based on the ideal of promoting peace and stability is IMO very sound.

 But the point is that the majority of American people do not trust the U.N. If the organization was comprised of truly democratic nations without an agenda of France (that's the other problem), the whole Iraq scenario would have been different, in my opinion. There is no question but that Cheney and Rumsfeld were intent on removing Saddam long before the war began. Powell wanted to go the diplomatic route. He was told it was a waste of time. His back-stabbing counterpoint in France caused him to do a complete about face. Even in your own life you know those who are straight shooters and those who are dishonest and not above board. Same for me. If I already believe that someone is going to do a number on me I am much, much less inclined to listen to them even if they happen to be right. The U.N. is no longer believed to be acting in the international interest and certainly not in our interest. To say that the U.N. needs reform is the understatement of the century.

 You mean, you don`t want any country to participate in the organisation? Let`s face it, every single country has an agenda. Every single politician has an agenda. Wether it is ideologicly fueled, fueled by private economic interests, maximation of domestic aproval ratings, zero-sum power politics etc, etc. By dissmissing France as self-serving and only in it for their own interests/agenda, I think you are summing up the european view of the US pretty nicely. Wether it is true or not is naturally up for discussion, but in my view, every political leader has an agenda. And the agenda itself is perhaps not as important as the result.

 UN is a forum for debate and decission-making. It is what its members make it to be. If there are political differences between its members, there will naturally be problems with reaching a decission. 
 
 The reason why the UN "doesn`t act in the interest of the US" is that the members of UN do not want the UN to act in the interests of the US. The reason for this is certainly debatable, but intuitively two things strikes me as the most probable causes; 1:US isn`t well thought off by the rest of the world to such a degree that national politicians can reap huge political rewards by obstructing US interests. 2: US interests do not correlate with the interests of the UN members (the rest of the world). Perhaps this is because US leadership percieve a problem and a war that the rest of the world doesn`t percieve.

 I respectfully disagree with you. It was the U.N. that permitted and encouraged the fiasco and outrageous Oil for Food scandal to drag on for many years. By any objective standard Saddam benefited from the U.N.; certainly not the U.S. It was the belief (grounded on fact) that led Saddam to flout the 17 U.N. sanctions; that were if complied with, would have permitted Iraq to rejoin the "family of nations" and normal trade relations. 
 
 The bottom line is that the U.N. as it currently operates is a malignant cancer. It is worse than useless. Either it reforms to create a level playing field or it should be abolished.
Eddie

 But this is the thing. Who initiated the oil-for-food programe? Who authorized the oil-for-food programe Who enforced the oil-for-food programe?It was not UN as an organisation. It was its member countries. It was not UN that permited the oil for food scandals. It was the members that insisited on retaining the programe even though it was apparant it had huge flaws and created great suffering in the Iraqi people. 
 
 It was not UN that "allowed" Saddam to flaunt UN sactions. It was the members that didn`t want to enforce the sanctions. Without UN, I don`t really see how things would be better... Do you think the wrold had been silent when US forces marched into Bagdhad just becasue there was no UN? In what way does the UN pose a problem, or cancer if you will?

 Of course you are right in one sense. It is those members and their acquiesance that bothers me. But it has taken a life of its own and the slate needs to be wiped clean. 
 
 What good is the U.N. really? They stood by and did nothing about Rwanda. The Balkans, nothing. Today, Darfur, nothing. What did they do when Soviet tanks were rumbling into Hungary or Czechslovakia? When China murdered 3,000 students in Tiannamen Square? When Pol Pot murdered 3,000,000 Cambodians? What good are they for except to line the pockets of a bunch of overpaid bureaucrats and striped pants "diplomats?" Bush was dead on accurate when he referred to them as a debating society. It is the facade of relevance that is the cancer. Get rid of it and at least we might have a possibility of achieving peace and justice; not the false promise that the U.N. currently offers.

 Let me explain something here. I don't spend my entire life on this board although it occasionally seems that way. I tend to skip over posts especially if they are long and rambling and try to address the most salient points. There is nothing wrong with just asking simple, direct questions. I'm unlikely to miss the question posed. I also have a developing vision problem and will have to have cateract surgery within the month. This is not to offer up an excuse but sometimes I just don't see what is printed there. 
 
 I did reread Eddie's post and he made a number of assertions. I could jump up and down and try to respond with my own take but I didn't necessarily see the point of it. For example what am I supposed to say to these questions?
 
 What life? What has UN, as an organisation done that would not have happened without it?
 
 And you do realise that america was one of those members who actively inititiated, authorized, enforced and defended the oil-for-food programme? 
 
 I could only speculate about the first question. The second carries with it assertions that I am not about to study about since it would take an inordinate amount of time and really is just a blanket assertion that we are somehow responsible for the oil for food mess. How would I possibly know when American officials knew something was amiss; when they started to express concerns, etc.?
 
 If I may offer up a suggestion to anyone who wants a direct response to a question, frame the question with some sense of what the facts are before asking the question. The way to know how this is done is to listen to a presidential news conference or any of the Sunday political programs. For example:  It can be factually stated that U.S. in consort with its allies in 1995 (I'm guessing) instituted the "oil for food" program in Iraq. Now the U.S. is claiming that the U.N. is corrupt and should be held accountable. Why didn't the U.S. go to the U.N. and bring this concern to their attention before the decision was made to go to war with Iraq. 
 
 That way I have a framework from which to reply. As it is now it simply a bare assertion that may or may not have any basis in reality any more than the question "when did you stop beating your wife?"
Truthsayer
